snippet: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in disaffected suburbs like Vaulx-en-Velin.
abstract: Many Muslims in French suburbs feel isolated from rest of country and believe attack on satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo will only intensify social and economic inequality they continue to experience; fear increase in racial profiling and general marginalization of immigrant communities.

byline.original: By ADAM B. ELLICK and LIZ ALDERMAN
byline.contributor: Adam B. Ellick reported from Vaulx-en-Velin, and Liz Alderman from Clichy-sous-Bois. Yann Cress contributed reporting from Clichy-sous-Bois, and Lisa Burek from Vaulx-en-Velin.

lead_paragraph: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in disaffected suburbs like Vaulx-en-Velin.

headline.main: Crisis in France Is Seen as Sign of Chronic Ills
headline.print_headline: Crisis in France Is Seen as Sign of Social Ills
